10/14/15 07:02 AM EDT
HRC plans Morristown fundraiser
We're working on more stories right now

                                            By 
                                                    POLITICO Magazine


                                            By 
                                                    Jeff Greenfield


                                            By 
                                                    Matt Latimer


                                            By 
                                                    POLITICO Magazine


Debate Night 

            By 
Alex Isenstadt

10/14/15 01:49 AM EDT
For months, Republicans have been positively giddy over the prospect of facing Hillary Clinton.
After Tuesday night, they might be having second thoughts.
Story Continued Below
Clinton, in the first debate of the Democratic primary season, came across as confident, crisp, in command of the issues — and anything but the wounded foe of Republican dreams.
“Hillary is the George Foreman of tonight’s #DemDebate — nobody can lay a glove on her,” tweeted GOP pollster Frank Luntz. “Very skillful responses tonight.”
But, questionable boxing references aside, other Republicans noted that her opponents in the ring were not exactly Muhammad Alis.
“As a debater, she did well. She was comfortable, confident, and articulate,” said Ari Fleischer, who served as press secretary in the George W. Bush White House. “But a general election race against her will be based on what she's done and not done — not on what she says.” 
With the pressure on, Clinton easily swatted away the questions that have dogged her throughout her campaign — from her use of a personal email account during her tenure as secretary of state, to accusations that she’s flip-flopped on key issues, to her past support for the Iraq war.



            By 
Nick Gass

She stared down Bernie Sanders, the socialist firebrand who has drawn waves of enthusiasm from liberal activists and pulled ahead of her in New Hampshire, challenging him on his opposition to some forms of gun control. If anything, Sanders’s most memorable line of the night came when he sprung to her defense over her email practices. “Enough with the damn emails,” he said to raucous applause, drawing a handshake from Clinton.
Back-of-the-packers Martin O’Malley, Lincoln Chafee, and Jim Webb, meanwhile, served mainly as curiosities.
To some Republicans, the former secretary of state’s performance sparked flashbacks to 2008, when she exhibited a steely discipline that made her a formidable debater. “She was precisely what I expected,” said Rick Wilson, a Florida-based Republican strategist. “Hyper-prepared, disciplined, constantly reinforcing her left flank.” 
Others conceded that she looked and sounded impressive. “Hillary Clinton was the only candidate on the stage this evening with the stature of a president,” said Alex Castellanos, a longtime Republican media consultant. “That helps.”
As they took in the GOP reaction, Democrats could barely contain their glee. “Republicans are crapping themselves tonight,” Brad Woodhouse, the president of Correct the Record, a pro-Clinton group, tweeted.
While Clinton’s performance heartened Democrats who have grown increasingly concerned about her lackluster campaign, it does not spell the end of her problems. 
Over the coming weeks, she will face ongoing scrutiny into her tenure as secretary of state — including later this month, when she appears before the congressional panel investigating the Benghazi attacks.
Few of Clinton’s rivals, Republicans contend, were willing to challenge her in any serious way — something she won’t be able to count on if she becomes the Democratic nominee. GOP groups used the debate to test-run attacks on the former secretary of state. America Rising, a Republican opposition research firm, pumped out waves of attacks on the Democratic front-runner, going after her email habits, her Wall Street ties, and her defense of President Obama.



            By 
Daniel Strauss

“I think she won the debate tonight, but faced little true opposition in doing so and told us very little about what kind of general election candidate she might be when she's truly contested,” said Bruce Haynes, a Republican operative who serves as president of the political consulting firm Purple Strategies.
Others blamed CNN. In the post-debate spin room, Sean Spicer, the Republican National Committee’s chief strategist, grumbled that the moderators weren’t forceful enough in pressing the Democratic front-runner on her view of the Black Lives Matter movement.
“She was let off the hook," he said.
But Clinton, some Republicans argued, might not have escaped the evening entirely unscathed. As Clinton swatted down her more liberal rivals, they noted, she was compelled to take stances that pushed her to the left — as when she voiced outspoken support of gun control legislation — that could hurt her later.
“She certainly didn't cover the spread,” said Kevin Madden, who served as a top official on Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential campaign, “and, in the process, stood and watched as her entire party got yanked far to the left.” 
“Small picture: HRC survives debate one,” tweeted Mike Murphy, a longtime Jeb Bush political adviser who is steering his super PAC. “Big picture: Dems lurch left, creating GOP opportunity.” He added later: “HRC + the D’s took some solid steps toward losing OH, VA, NC and FL in ’ tonight. I’ll take it.”
Sidestepping the questions surrounding her emails and her shifting policy positions might win her the night, others said, but wouldn’t serve her well in the long run.
“I don’t think Hillary did anything to address the character issues dogging her campaign,” said Eric Fehrnstrom, a former Mitt Romney aide. “There's a reason why Hillary's campaign has tried to keep a lid on the number of debates. It’s because they know that people don’t trust her, and that she doesn’t come across as a real person. She loses every time her opponents appear on the same stage with her.”
“What did Hillary add to what we know of her tonight? Nothing,” said Castellanos. “Say the same and you remain in the same place.” 
Hadas Gold contributed to this report.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Clinton impresses Republicans, but some see hints of weakness
